node.Description: This is a decision for a BPML selection problem that addresses...

node.Title: [Definition]
node.Description: (----------New Subcharacteristic--------)

node.Title: Communication
node.Description: Whether the technique facilitates understanding[COMMA] communicating or describing a process

node.Title: Analysis
node.Description: Whether the technique facilitates the analyzing (and improving) of a process

node.Title: Enaction
node.Description: Whether the technique facilitates the execution of a process[COMMA] and/or is generally used with the aim of creating executable models

node.Title: Control
node.Description: Whether the technique facilitates the and/or is generally used for the managing and monitoring of a process

node.Title: Functional
node.Description: What process elements / Functional dependencies between process elements (activities[COMMA] subprocesses[COMMA] etcetera)

node.Title: Dynamic/Behavioural
node.Description: When and how activities are performed

node.Title: Informational/Resource
node.Description: Data (entities) produced or manipulated by a process[COMMA] and their relationships. In other words[COMMA] the structure of informational entities

node.Title: Organizational
node.Description: Where and by whom activities are performed[COMMA] both functionally and physically.

node.Title: General-purpose ML
node.Description: Language is designed to be used for modeling the widest variety of application domains

node.Title: Textual
node.Description: The language notation is textual

node.Title: Graphical/Diagrammical
node.Description: The language notation is graphical

node.Title: Tabular
node.Description: Textual but with predefined tabular structure (often for natural language description of processes).

node.Title: Mathematical
node.Description: Graphical highly formal semtantics based on formal logic. Modeling requires knowledge about math and/or logic.

node.Title: Imperative
node.Description: Whether the language allows for for imperative modeling: Procedural. Processes with a clear start and clear end (state). E.g. workflows.

node.Title: Declarative
node.Description: Whether the language allows for declarative modeling: Knowledge intensive[COMMA] no clear start to end and many variatons possible (variations not all known in advance). For declarative approaches you define the boundaries and anything within the boundaries is possible.

node.Title: Control flow/Sequence
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the modeling of an order in which tasks are to be executed. In other words[COMMA] whether the language includes a concept of time

node.Title: Information flow/Message flow
node.Description: Whether the messages and their flow can be modeled

node.Title: Data flow
node.Description: Whether the language explicitly allows for the modeling of the flow of data

node.Title: Inclusive choice (OR)
node.Description: Whether the language contains the OR construct

node.Title: Exclusive choice (XOR)
node.Description: Whether the language contains the XOR construct

node.Title: Parallelism (AND)
node.Description: Whether the language contains the AND construct[COMMA] e.g. Flowchart does not have this

node.Title: Input
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the modeling process input. Typically[COMMA] these are resources referenced and/or consumed by activities/tasks/functions

node.Title: Output
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the modeling of deliverables or output[COMMA] e.g. the creation of a document

node.Title: External entities
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the explicit modeling of external entities that perform a certain process element

node.Title: Agent (Roles/Entitites)
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the explicit modeling of actors[COMMA] roles and organizational units that perform a certain process element. An entity is a definable thing[COMMA] such as a person object concept or event[COMMA] that can have data stored about it

node.Title: Duration
node.Description: Whether there is a construct to depict duration[COMMA] represent a time span[COMMA] the passage of time[COMMA] or a specific point in time (e.g. a day of the week)

node.Title: Deadline
node.Description: Whether there is a construct to depict the time period within activities or tasks have to be carried out

node.Title: Business rules
node.Description: Whether language allows for the modeling of business rules

node.Title: Business goals
node.Description: Whether language allows for the explicit modeling of business goals (note: a final state is not considered a process goal for this feature)

node.Title: Annotation
node.Description: Whether language allows for textual annotation in addition the graphical representation of a process. Textual annotation can be used to provide additional details about a process element[COMMA] that otherwise could not be depicted.

node.Title: Task/Activity
node.Description: Whether the language has a ""task"" or ""activity"" construct

node.Title: Event/Trigger
node.Description: Whether the language has an ""event"" construct. An event is an occurance that takes place at a specific point in time[COMMA] and that is capable of inducing some behaviour (e.g. acitivity or process)

node.Title: Mappability
node.Description: Whether the language has a formal specification for mapping to an Executable Business Process (Modeling) Language

node.Title: Standardized file format
node.Description: Whether the language has a standard file format specified

node.Title: XML
node.Description: Extensible Markup Language: a set of codes or tags that describes the text in a digital document. More broad than XSD and XMI

node.Title: PNML
node.Description: Petri Net Markup Language[COMMA] XML-based interchange format for Petri Net files

node.Title: XSD (XML Schema Definition)
node.Description: Defines what elements and attributes may appear in XML document

node.Title: XMI (XML Metadata Interchange)
node.Description: File format used to store model design information in standard XML format

node.Title: yawl-XML
node.Description: YAWL-XML[COMMA] file format specifically used for yawl files

node.Title: EPML
node.Description: EPC Markup Language[COMMA] neutral interchange format that facilitates interchange of EPC business process models

node.Title: Execution Engine Availability
node.Description: Whether there are any Execution Engines available that support the (automatic) simulation of the models of a given language

node.Title: Simulation support
node.Description: Whether the language allows for simulation (enaction of the model)

node.Title: Verification support
node.Description: Whether the language allows for qualitative analysis[COMMA] e.g. The detecting of deadlocks[COMMA] races[COMMA] etcetera

node.Title: True concurrency
node.Description: Whether the language allows for true-parallelism[COMMA] explicitly representing steps that can be performed by different workers.

node.Title: System Interpretation
node.Description: Whether the output model of the language is to be used or interpreted by systems

node.Title: Decomposition
node.Description: Whether the language allows for decomposition / process nesting

node.Title: High-level support
node.Description: Whether the language allows for high-level modeling (top-down approach)

node.Title: Low-level support
node.Description: Whether the language allows for low-level modeling (bottom-up approach) with detailed descriptions of atomic activities

node.Title: State-based
node.Description: Whether the modeling language allows for modeling of state-based models

node.Title: Activity-based
node.Description: Whether the language allows for the modeling of activity/task-based models

node.Title: Novice
node.Description: Whether the language is generally perceived as being suitable/understandable for/by novice modelers

node.Title: Expert
node.Description: Whether the language is generally perceived as being suitable/understandable for/by or tailored to experts or well-experienced modelers

node.Title: Graphical economy
node.Description: The degree of the number of unique graphical symbols the language has (Note: The assumption is made that a higher amount results in lower understandability[COMMA] but higher expressiveness). Featured not applicable (=0) to textual process modeling languages.

node.Title: Visual emphasis: colour
node.Description: Whether the language uses color as additional differentiating factor for the notation of elements

node.Title: Formality (clear definition of rules)
node.Description: The degree of formality: the extend to which a language has well defined semantics and rules to be followed

node.Title: Perceptual discriminatibility
node.Description: Extent to which symbols are clearly distinguishable[COMMA] as perceived in literature

node.Title: Semantic transparency
node.Description: Self describing: extent to which meaning of symbol can be inferred from its appearance[COMMA] as perceived in literature

node.Title: Organizational body
node.Description: Whether there is an organization behind the language[COMMA] actively responsible for version management and development of the language[COMMA] e.g. OMG

node.Title: Conformity to standard
node.Description: Whether the technique is conform to an ISO standard

node.Title: Evolutionary
node.Description: Whether new and improved versions have been released over time

node.Title: Theoretical Foundation
node.Description: The level of theoretical support for the business process modeling technique (i.e. whether its has its foundations in the academic domain)

node.Title: Documentation availability
node.Description: Availability of a comprehensive and well-documented manual or language specification

node.Title: Active community
node.Description: Whether the technique has an active community. An active community is defined as a group of people (modelers) gathered in a place to achieve a common goal (in this case being an online forum or an active research community)

node.Title: HR availability
node.Description: Degree of expert availability (*may vary over time)

node.Title: Training material availability (degree)
node.Description: The degree of training material availability

node.Title: YouTube availability
node.Description: Whether there are instructional youtube videos available about the technique (Language: EN)

node.Title: Course availability
node.Description: Whether there are courses available at recognized organizations[COMMA] e.g. UvA or UU[COMMA] about the technique

node.Title: Blog/Article availability
node.Description: Whether there are blogs / articles available about the technique

node.Title: Degree of Popularity
node.Description: The degree of popularity of the given technique (3 = very popular)

node.Title: tool availability (degree)
node.Description: The degree of tool availability for both free and paid tools combined

node.Title: free tools availability
node.Description: Whether there are any free tools available that support the modeling using a certain technique

node.Title: open-source tools availability
node.Description: Whether there are any open source tools available that support the modeling using a certain technique
